clefs.tab.name: 6stringTabClef
clefs.tab.note: SMuFL defines two tab clefs, one for a 4-line staff and one for 6. I plan to make them both aliases for clefs.tab.

clefs.change_combining.name: clefChangeCombining
clefs.change_combining.note: Emmentaler needs this combining glyph in order for the ligature clefs to work as expected.

plus.name: timeSigPlus
plus.note: SMuFL distinguishes timeSigPlus, which adds entire signatures together, from timeSigPlusSmall, which only adds numerators. I plan on making them both aliases of plus.

period.name: timeSigDot
period.note: Since most of the related symbols begin with timeSig-, I opted to do the same here.

period.name: timeSigPeriod
period.note: -Dot is attested in SMuFL (keyboardPedalDot); -Period is not.

zero.name: timeSig0
zero.note: SMuFL specifies three distinct number sets; timeSigX seems to match ours the best. (1-9 are the same as 0.)

zero.small.name: figbass0
zero.small.note: A xxx.small number set will probably need to be created in the future.

accidentals.sharp.name: accidentalWyschnegradsky6TwelfthsSharp
accidentals.sharp.note: I wonder if it's fair to users if we claim to support Wyschnegradsky accidentals if we only really have three of SMuFL's full set of 22.

accidentals.sharp.arrowup.name: accidentalSharpOneArrowUp
accidentals.sharp.arrowup.note: The arrow is in a different place. This fact, along with the differing arrowhead style, suggests we shouldn't encode this accidental set or the Stockhausen set at all.

accidentals.sharp.arrowboth.name: accidentalSharpArrowsUpAndDown
accidentals.sharp.arrowboth.note: We could name it -TwoArrows or -BothArrows, but I think this is fine.

accidentals.sharp.slashslash.stem.name: accidentalKomaSharp
accidentals.sharp.slashslash.stem.note: This one seems a tad wider than the others, but I don't see it as too much of a problem.

accidentals.sharp.slashslashslash.stemst.name: accidentalThreeQuarterTonesSharpStockhausen
accidentals.sharp.slashslashslash.stemst.note: Resemblance is dubious. Besides, given our other Stockhausen troubles, it's probably best not to bother.

accidentals.sharp.slash.stem.name: accidentalRaiseOneUndecimalQuartertone
accidentals.sharp.slash.stem.note: Doesn't quite match the Emmentaler glyph's proportions, but it doesn't seem like too much of a problem to me.

accidentals.sharp.slash.stem.name: accidentalOneQuarterToneSharpStockhausen
accidentals.sharp.slash.stem.note: Doesn't match the Emmentaler glyph's proportions; plus, it's Stockhausen.

accidentals.natural.arrowup.name: accidentalNaturalOneArrowUp
accidentals.natural.arrowup.note: See the above note on the arrowed sharps.

accidentals.natural.arrowdown.name: accidentalNaturalOneArrowDown
accidentals.natural.arrowdown.note: See the above note on the arrowed sharps.

accidentals.natural.arrowboth.name: accidentalNaturalArrowsUpAndDown
accidentals.natural.arrowboth.note: We could name it -TwoArrows or -BothArrows, but I think this is fine.

accidentals.flat.arrowup.name: accidentalFlatOneArrowUp
accidentals.flat.arrowup.note: See the above note on the arrowed sharps.

accidentals.flat.arrowdown.name: accidentalFlatOneArrowDown
accidentals.flat.arrowdown.note: See the above note on the arrowed sharps.

accidentals.flat.arrowboth.name: accidentalFlatArrowsUpAndDown
accidentals.flat.arrowboth.note: We could name it -TwoArrows or -BothArrows, but I think this is fine.

accidentals.flat.slash.name: accidentalOneQuarterToneFlatStockhausen
accidentals.flat.slash.note: Honestly, this one looks identical to the others. But if I'm not doing Stockhausen, I'm not doing Stockhausen.

accidentals.mirroredflat.backslash.name: accidentalReversedFlatSlash
accidentals.mirroredflat.backslash.note: What accidental system uses this? Might inform our name choice.

accidentals.mirroredflat.backslash.name: accidentalMirroredFlatSlash
accidentals.mirroredflat.backslash.note: -Reversed- is attested in SMuFL (e.g. accidentalReversedFlatArrowUp); -Mirrored- is not.

accidentals.flatflat.slash.name: accidentalDoubleFlatSlash
accidentals.flatflat.slash.note: What accidental system uses this? Might inform our name choice.

noteheads.uM2.name: noteheadLongaUp
noteheads.uM2.note: No analog found in Bravura. Because of their hardcoded stems, these glyphs look more like Bravura's "Individual notes" glyphs (i.e. noteHalfUp). However, those glyphs are not meant for direct music engraving.

noteheads.dM2.name: noteheadLongaDown
noteheads.dM2.note: It looks like we hardcoded the stems here to make sure they fit nicely with the sidebars. This is probably a discussion for elsewhere, but is that really the best solution? It would take some work, but perhaps we should refrain from encoding (single-bar) breve and longa glyphs, and instead draw their bars with primitives to match the stem.

noteheads.s0triangle.name: noteheadTriangleDownWhole
noteheads.s0triangle.note: This and the following matchups are highly debatable, so I opted to define a new notehead group instead.

noteheads.s2slash.name: noteheadSlashHorizontalEnds
noteheads.s2slash.note: For some reason Bravura includes a version with vertical line ends, which is why this glyph name specifies horizontal ends.

noteheads.s2xcircle.name: noteheadHalfWithX
noteheads.s2xcircle.note: A lot of options here. It seems that mapping them all should work just fine.

noteheads.s0harmonic.name: noteheadDiamondWhole
noteheads.s0harmonic.note: SMuFL-using programs will expect the -Diamond- set to be visually cohesive, so we should encode both -Whole and -Half as aliases for -.s0harmonic.

noteheads.s0do.name: noteShapeTriangleUpWhite
noteheads.s0do.note: SMuFL's coverage of shape notes is rather poor, missing many inverted glyphs, so be warned: I've had to add quite a few new base glyph names throughout this section.

noteheads.s1do.note: I think the reason to distinguish -.s1xx from -.s0xx disappeared with commit 2d460deb (Define notehead attachment points separately); indeed, I've found every pair's generating code to be functionally identical and not worth encoding twice. (Further -s1xx's in the Aiken and Funk sets will be omitted for brevity; see the Walker section for a small exception.)

noteheads.u0doFunk.name: noteShapeMoonRightWhite
noteheads.u0doFunk.note: SMuFL has only one set for all shape-note systems. For clarity, we should add suffixes to our non-Aiken sets and make them stylistic alternates of the unsuffixed glyphs. Our glyphs should also have unsuffixed aliases when not already defined in the Aiken set.

noteheads.s0solFunk.name: noteShapeRoundWhiteWalker
noteheads.s0solFunk.note: -sXsolFunk is used in both our Funk set and our Walker set. It should receive aliases for both so that other programs don't get confused.

noteheads.s0doWalker.note: Our Walker glyphs distinguish whole from half notes in only one respect: whole notes appear to face downwards all the time. It seems to me that that sort of difference would be better defined within the \walkerHeads command rather than in the font, which would allow us to remove more redundant glyphs. Thoughts? (From now on, -.s0xxWalker glyphs will be omitted for brevity.)

noteheads.d1doWalker.name: noteShapeKeystoneUprightWhite
noteheads.d1doWalker.note: SMuFL's description for -Keystone- states that it is an 'Inverted keystone'. Therefore, it seems natural to me to call this one -KeystoneUpright-.

noteheads.d1reWalker.name: noteShapeQuarterMoonLeftWhite
noteheads.d1reWalker.note: This seems like the best naming option, even though SMuFL's -QuarterMoon- glyph names don't indicate -Right-.

scripts.lcomma.name: breathMarkCommaInverted
scripts.lcomma.note: Is this primarily a chant thing or a modern notation thing? Might inform our name choice. EDIT: it's modern notation.

scripts.rvarcomma.name: breathMarkCommaStraight
scripts.rvarcomma.note: If anyone at all uses this thing for actual breath marks and not just chant, I say we add this name. EDIT: Turns out it's only chant.

scripts.lvarcomma.name: chantCaesuraInverted
scripts.lvarcomma.note: This glyph was added for parity, and has no actual use in chant. Still, it remains a chant glyph.

scripts.lvarcomma.name: breathMarkCommaStraightInverted
scripts.lvarcomma.note: Is this primarily a chant thing or a modern notation thing? Might inform our name choice. EDIT: See directly above.

scripts.arpeggio.name: wiggleArpeggiatoUp
scripts.arpeggio.note: It looks like these glyphs are rotated in SMuFL. I'm thinking we create new glyphs according to their specs, while preserving our own for backwards compatibility.

scripts.trill_element.name: ornamentZigZagLineNoRightEnd
scripts.trill_element.note: LilyPond uses trill_element, not trillelement, for trills, right? Edit: Yes.

scripts.trill_element.name: ornamentZigZagLineWithRightEnd
scripts.trill_element.note: SMuFL places this variant at the right end of a trill; since LilyPond just repeats the same trill_element throughout, it'll just be another alias of trill_element.

scripts.trillelement.name: ornamentZigZagLineShortened
scripts.trillelement.note: Does LilyPond use this glyph? What for? Edit: seems to be an old, unused trill_element. I'm making up a SMuFL name for it, but if we delete it there obviously won't be need for one.

scripts.prallmordent.name: ornamentTrillMordent
scripts.prallmordent.note: This and the following ornaments can be described as ligatures of the SMuFL 'Combining strokes for trills and mordents' glyphs--something for the bucket list.

scripts.upprall.name: ornamentUpTrill
scripts.upprall.note: Never mind. I missed that SMuFL already has all these guys!

scripts.pralldown.name: ornamentPrecompTrillLowerSuffix
scripts.pralldown.note: LilyPond's glyph has three trill element repetitions, while this SMuFL glyph, the closest analog I could find, only has 2. Would it be worth it to give our glyph a new SMuFL name instead of this one?

scripts.augmentum.name: chantAugmentum
scripts.augmentum.note: dots.dotvaticana already fills this function; it appears that this glyph has remained unused since its creation. I think it should be deleted.

scripts.dsignumcongruentiae.name: mensuralSignumDown
scripts.dsignumcongruentiae.note: These symbols appear to be mirrored, but it doesn't seem like much of an issue to me.

pedal.Ped.name: keyboardPedalPed
pedal.Ped.note: This is a base glyph in SMuFL. I wonder if there's any way to map a SMuFL base name to a sequence of Emmentaler glyphs...

pedal.Ped.name: keyboardPedalPedNoDot
pedal.Ped.note: This is a recommended stylistic alternate.

accordion.oldEE.name: accdnOld88
accordion.oldEE.note: I can't figure out what this is. -OldEE is a holdover from another way we used to encode accordion symbols, almost all eradicated by 2004. The E's stand for 8' stops (as opposed to 2' [T], 4' [F], or 16' [S]), so it might be an old version of the violin or musette register for the 3-rank system. However, I haven't found it used in any actual sheet music on the internet. Not even my accordionist friend knows what to make of it! Linked are SMuFL's accordion page and a notation guide I found, neither of which have the symbol:

custodes.vaticana.u0.name: chantCustosStemUpPosSpace
custodes.vaticana.u0.note: SMuFL defines six variants of a Custos: StemUpPos[Middle/Low/Lowest] and StemDownPos[Middle/High/Highest]. We use a different (more correct) system, where 0 = space, 1 = line, and 2 = anywhere.

noteheads.svaticana.vlpes.name: chantPodatusLowerAdjacent
noteheads.svaticana.vlpes.note: This is a LilyPond-only variant for when the upper and lower notes of a pes (AKA podatus) are adjacent to one another and need to be modified to prevent collision.

noteheads.smedicaea.rvirga.name: chantPunctumVirgaInvertedMedicaea
noteheads.smedicaea.rvirga.note: 'Inverted' is attested in SMuFL as a flip on the horizontal axis (or a 180-degree rotation), and so is better suited to this glyph than 'Reversed', which in SMuFL indicates merely a left-right reversal.

noteheads.smedicaea.rvirga.name: chantPunctumVirgaReversedMedicaea
noteheads.smedicaea.rvirga.note: SMuFL has vaticana-style glyphs called chantPunctumVirga(Reversed), but they aren't the same orientation as these Medicaea ones. (We don't have Vaticana virga glyphs anyway--we make ours with a punctum and stem.) Perhaps a better naming scheme is in order? EDIT: See above for a solution.

clefs.hufnagel.do.fa.name: chantCFclefHufnagel
clefs.hufnagel.do.fa.note: I'm calling this an alternate of the C clef because its center is defined in parmesan-clefs.mf as the center of the C clef part.

noteheads.shufnagel.virga.name: chantPunctumVirgaHufnagel
noteheads.shufnagel.virga.note: It seems we ought to add chantPunctumVirga(Reversed) to our Vaticana set, even if it's only used by non-LilyPond programs. That way we can make this and the Medicaea variants proper alternates of expected SMuFL glyphs. EDIT: No, we shouldn't. This is way too niche.
